primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: Jesus, the true and weak King, enters Jerusalem to bear judgment and reclaim his rightful authority over the human heart, which is currently enslaved to false 'kings'.

tekstueel_bewijs: He went on ahead, going up to Jerusalem
He sent two of his disciples
He makes us more ourselves than ever before

object.identificatie: The restoration of the King's authority/The heart of the hearer
tekstueel_bewijs: He can’t change your life... unless you understand him as King
I come to take the divine wrath... so I can forgive you
Jesus is trying to fulfill Scripture
The one who comes in the name of the Lord
The last breath Jesus breathed on this planet was for you

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit (implied as indwelling power) and the 'Weakness' of the Cross
tekstueel_bewijs: He comes not to bring judgment; I come to bear judgment
He is the only one... who can control us without destroying us
Whatever you live for... it's a lord. It's a master.
The great Serpent, the great Dragon of evil and suffering
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad habits but 'divine wrath' and 'cosmic evil' that requires a King's death to defeat.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer's response: Worship, Obedience, and Expectation as a consequence of the King's arrival.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.object: A life aligned with the 'grain of the universe'
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics/response) is explicitly grounded in the primary program (soteriology). One cannot obey (S2) until one is freed by the Weak King (S1).

voorbeelden_god_subject: He will trample on the Serpent
He makes us more ourselves than ever before
voorbeelden_mens_subject: You have to live for something

voorbeelden: You have to obey him unconditionally
The things that capture your imagination are the things you serve
You can’t know Jesus Christ unless you know him as King
He is the only one who can control us without destroying us

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes the 'Pouvoir' (Power/Ability) of Jesus to do what the hearer cannot: defeat the 'oppressive lords' of the heart.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From the illusion of Autonomy (~S1) to the realization of being under Oppressive Lords (S2), then to the Weak King (S1), resulting in Freedom (S1/S2 synthesis).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by the 'Weakness' of the King; his death on the cross satisfies the 'Oppressive' requirements of justice, allowing for a non-oppressive rule.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. Idolatry is described as a 'poison' that 'punishes' and 'destroys' the hearer.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon contains many imperatives (obey, worship), they are framed as the 'natural water' for a fish. The 'engine' of the sermon is Christ's substitutionary work as the Weak King.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: You have to worship him, you have to obey him...

indicatoren_genade.indicator: Subject-Switch (Christ as the only capable actor)
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: I come to take the divine wrath... that the human race deserves
The great Dragon of evil... he will trample on the Serpent

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures (disciples, Jonah) are used as negative examples or functional actants, not as moral heroes to emulate.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already focuses on God's action through these figures.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the burden of self-salvation (idolatry).
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic sanctification: the King's presence produces the change.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'True King' (Mind) to 'Weak King' (Heart) to 'Your King' (Will) is logically and narratively integrated.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'unconditional obedience' and 'freedom' is resolved through the metaphor of the fish in water.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: I come to take the divine wrath on human sin that the human race deserves

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The King provides the 'Pouvoir' by 'calming the sea' of the heart.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is an oppressive master that 'gobbles poison' and requires a cosmic rescue.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God/Christ as the primary Subject of the 'Heavy' verbs (saving, bearing wrath, transforming), while placing the hearer in the role of Receiver who then becomes a secondary Subject of response.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly high on Devoir (Must) in the final third.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Ensure the 'Pouvoir' (Power) of the Spirit is explicitly linked to the 'Devoir' (Obedience).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Explicitly state that the 'Weak King' provides the very desire (Vouloir) he commands.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in Christocentric narrative structure. The sermon avoids moralism by redefining 'Lordship' not as human effort but as the only safe environment for the human soul.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'Mind/Will/Heart' structure; Greimas reveals that the 'Heart' section is actually the actantial engine that enables the 'Will' section.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the donkey; Greimas shows the donkey is a 'Helper' actant that qualifies the Subject's (Jesus) mode of power.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that 'idolatry' in this sermon is not just a sin but a competing 'Subject' that seeks to occupy the throne of the hearer.

volledige_subject_lijst: Jesus (sent, went, said, comes, bears, takes, forgives, forces, rides)
The Hearer (serves, crowns, lives for, obeys, worships, expects)
appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Weak King' paradox to shift the hearer from a Subject of their own life to a Receiver of Christ's life.
